remixed_from.author: ericskiff
remixed_from.title: Laptop Stand with steampunk gear design

description.text: I thought this stand would look great with a vintage subway map on it. I found just the map on Wikimedia commons. There are a couple of probems with the uploaded file: (1) The left and right pieces have sections with double lines. This will run the laser over the outline twice. If you're paying for laser time, this is 4-6 minutes you can cut out if you clean the file up. (2) The slots in the base piece are a little thin for the 1/8" acrylic I used. In fact, both sides were tight and snapped when I forced them together. The stand you see in my pictures has generous amounts of Krazy glue holding it together. (3) The prongs on the front that keep the laptop from slipping forward are a bit short. They don't work well with the curved edges of some laptops. My MacBook Pro barely holds, my HP Pavillion and Acer Aspire both slip off. If I can get on a computer with CorelDraw, I'll clean up the files and repost. The original map image can be found here: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Bmt1912.jpg, but I've uploaded a high-contrast version I used. More photos here: http://www.flickr.com/photos/mattmillr/sets/72157623972822062/.

comments.text: You could try coating the tops of the acryic supports with something non-skid, such as rubber cement or something similar.  I am interested in trying acrylic in my Epilog.  I have some ideas that I hope would work nice using it.

author: maburke

description.text: Megaman by Rubetoman [created on 3DTin]
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001
Guilty Crown by Borja [created on 3DTin]

I added longer/ more attachment points since previous version drooped down on the fan side and ruined otherwise fine prints that way. I made slots for the nuts so they don't fall and hide under the table when you open up the extruder head to clear a plug or whatever... I also added a shovel on one end which is intended to be used to shove small robust prints off the printing surface, so you can print another one...
(this is untested)

0) change something in the openscad file: the zip contains the base model and the scad file. (optional)
1) print (with whatever settings you use for something that's supposed to be structurally sound)
2) insert nuts (the were almost impossible to insert in my prototype version, so I added 0.1 mm clearance, I hope that's not to much, let me know)
3) mount
4a) invent gcode to push stuff of the printing surface and (optional)
4b) print something I could easily upload one with just the arms and no shovel at the end if someone wants that (it does make the printer head footprint bigger in Cura's project planner, never head of it check it out http://daid.github.com/Cura/?page=Project%20planner)

comments.text: Too much of a funnel, which will be obtrusive to the airflow.
comments.author: mikedeklerk

description.text: Inspired by TOPS Science's baby jar galvanometer http://www.topscience.org/activities_print/FreeDownload19.pdf This is a simple way to measure current.

I took a Trader Joe's Juice Sweetened Jelly Jar bent two paper clips on each side to hold the axle.  I then covered the paperclips in a layer of tape and wrapped 100 turns of 24 AWG wire around it.  After I printed the axle/pointer I fitted a small (6mmx6mm) neodymium magnet into the magnet hole and place it inside the jar.  Lastly, I stripped the ends of the wires and tested it.  It works!!  Now I am off to calibrate it.

comments.text: Just think how sensitive you could make this thing if you put in slots in the "arms" for razor blade pivots rather than counting on rolling. :-)
comments.author: foxpup

comments.text: Let your internal optimizer run wild!  I designed it to measure the output of a windmill generator so it is as accurate as it needs to be, but I wonder how good it could be. Hmm...
comments.author: foxpup

description.text: This is a 3d printable square tubing connector. I am using it for a rack for my mining rig.

This part is not press fit, it fits loosely in the tube, to make it fit snugly I would suggest using foam backed double stick tape on one side of the part.  
I printed with 10% infill and had no issues.  
If you are using it to build a mining rig stand I would suggest doing 10% infill also. You will also need foam backed double stick tape to fir the connectors.

title: Prusa i3 Single Frame Spool Holder

description.text:
Another i3 Single Frame Spool Holder  
This one attach to the backside of the Z-Axis top mounts using 20mm M3 bolts and nuts and uses 8mm smooth rods on top and sides. I used an old 370 mm smooth rod for the top to hold the spool or 2 spools and cut another one in half for the sides.  
Sides can be cut to any length you want, within reason. Threaded rod could be used on the sides but I won't use them on the top.

description.text:
This arrow is very simple to print.
if you made it let me know!!! have fun

print it on 100% infill
and put it on your arrow

My Sony Vaio was getting black screens and when I opened I checked that the LVDS cable (the one that connects the screen to the motherboard) was getting loose. My first attempt was just to press it, making the screen work again for a couple of weeks.  
Then the screen went black again, but this time I designed a simple clip and printed it. After printing a couple to get the correct size (didn't have the right tools to measure + not so precise printer), I put the clip on the loose side of the plug (2nd photo).   
Voila! Several months have passed and the screen is still working. Saved me hundreds from specialized support.  
This is probably the most valuable piece I ever printed! (and a easy answer to all those "what you do with a 3d printer??")  
As each laptop are different, the supplied clip will hardly fits. I suggest to change the design, size, etc (included blend file for referece).

• Check if this would fix your problem
  • Measure the plug and connectors
  • Re-design and/or resize supplied file and print it!

Parametric servo arms generator with OpenSCAD. Download last version on GitHub : https://github.com/hugokernel/OpenSCAD_ServoArms

Easy to use : servo_standard(20, 4); first parameter : the arm size second parameter : the arm count That's it ! Print settings with Cura :
  • Speed : 50mm/s
  • Fill density : 100%
    • Best result with ABS.
